After many hours in the game my enjoyment has started to decrease as I have noticed a few consistent issues. The "meta" of the game devolves into incentivizing cheesy uncreative tactics such as scps bolting to light containment to kill unarmed people who have spawned making it difficult to escape without hiding in a corner or getting lucky. There is spawn camping the opposing team (this one kills the vibe the most for me), grenade trapping elevators (also spawn camping a little bit), camping specific choke points for long periods of time, grouping up with unrealistic mass of 10-20 team members in a cluster (or all your scp team) for damage and protection. All these tactics make it less fun for me because when I die to these tactics I have to spectate for 5+ minutes waiting to respawn in which when I do respawn the same tactics above will most probably send me back to spectator mode and which further incentivizes me to play more cheesy by camping and hiding to preserve my life which makes the game significantly more boring and when I want to play exciting by taking risks and plays I most likely will be sent back to the spectator screen. 

Furthermore it makes the game feel like a macro game where your choices dont really matter that much and its up to how your team plays that decide the victory. Also to elaborate on the macro point the respawn system can feel a bit frustrating at times where you spawn as mtf team and your entire team gets wiped out because they played poorly and you survived by playing smart but you will end up dying because the chaos team will spawn next which is going to be all the people who died as mtf but they know exactly where you are, what guns/items you have, how many teammates you have because they are in spectating mode so its you vs 20 people spawning with that knowledge and there is few ways to even the playing field and it incentivizes dying when your team dies because of that exact hopeless situation.

All that said its still a great game that gave me many hours of enjoyment and I am just nitpicking balance issues that have killed the vibe for me recently.

SCP: Secret Laboratory is a free multiplayer horror game where 30+ people spawn into a secret underground facility and immediately prove why the SCP Foundation should never have trusted *anyone* with keycards.

The premise is simple: a containment breach at Site-02.
The experience is not:

* Class-D: orange jumpsuit, zero rights, 100% running in the wrong direction.
* Scientists: same as Class-D but with a tie and slightly more panic.
* Guards / MTF: show up late, underpaid, and expected to fix *everything*.
* Chaos: show up even later to shoot anyone with a security badge and call it “liberation.”
* SCPs: concrete peanut, plague doctor, shy guy, murder dog, angry computer, etc., all here to speedrun your obituary.

---

### Pros

* **Completely free** and still getting updates, which is wild for a game whose main mechanic is “blink and die.”
* Proximity voice chat means every hallway is either:

  * Pure tactical comms
  * Or 4 people screaming “CLOSE THE DOOR” in 12 different accents.
* Every round is a random role + random layout facility, so you never know if you’ll spawn as a scientist with a keycard… or as SCP-173 in a room full of soon-to-be neck problems.
* Factions all have different goals: escape, contain, “cure,” or just make sure nobody leaves alive. It’s like Among Us, if being sus was legally justified.

---

### Cons

* New player experience:

  * Spawn in
  * Pick up a keycard
  * Open one door
  * Instantly turned into neck confetti by SCP-173.
* You will get betrayed by Class-D, Chaos, *and* your own “teammates” closing doors on you “by accident.”
* Half of your deaths come from SCPs, the other half from elevators and “friendly fire that totally didn’t look like on purpose.”
* Public lobbies are 50% incredible roleplay, 50% improv comedy with light war crimes.

---

### Peak SCP:SL Moments

* Entire group staring at 173, one guy blinks IRL, all of you scream anyway.
* Chaos and MTF meeting in a hallway, instantly turning it into a very loud, very short-lived democracy.
* Escaping as Class-D, feeling proud… then getting gunned down by Chaos because they “didn’t recognize you.”
* Playing as an SCP with full comms, coordinating like a deadly esports team while your victims yell in proximity chat about “balance.”

---

Some people (like me) have a problem with launching the game with steam. I did however find a workaround which isn't to hard to do, that is:
1. Right-clicking the game (on the column with all your games)
2. Hover over manage
3. Click "Browse local files"
4. Look for the "SCPSL.EXE" file (could just be "SCPSL" depending on what settings you have on your file explorer)
5. Dubble left-click on the file and the game should start as normal except the steam overlay and other steam features

Overall the game is fun to play, and with the interactions you can have with other people it can be way more fun, but there are some downsides like learning curves, infuriating rounds, and the optimization. But since it's free im gonna have to give it a strong 8.9/10!

SCP: Secret Laboratory — Chaos, Tension, and Teamplay
Rating:
★★★★☆ (4/5)
*SCP: Secret Laboratory* (SCP:SL) is a multiplayer horror/action game set in a mysterious underground facility during a containment breach. Players take on different roles—Class-D, Scientists, MTF, Chaos Insurgency, or SCP entities—and must either escape, survive, or take advantage of the chaos depending on their objectives.
Every match plays differently thanks to the role variety, and the game’s tension-filled SCP universe atmosphere makes each round unpredictable and fun.
---
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
1. [b]Wide Variety of Playable Roles[/b]
   The game includes many different classes such as Class-D, Scientists, MTF units, Chaos Insurgency members, and of course SCPs. This creates tons of strategic variety and ensures no two matches feel the same.
2. [b]Intense Atmosphere and Horror Elements[/b]
   The dark facility, ambient sounds, and unpredictable containment breach events create a genuinely tense environment. The SCP universe’s sense of mystery and danger is captured very well.
3. [b]Community and Multiplayer Interaction[/b]
   SCP:SL has an active community and heavily relies on teamwork and communication. Proximity voice chat adds depth to strategic play and leads to hilarious (and chaotic) moments.
4. [b]Free-to-Play[/b]
   The game is completely free, making it easily accessible for anyone curious about the SCP universe or multiplayer horror games.
5. [b]Consistently Updated[/b]
   The developers frequently update the game with balance changes, bug fixes, and new content, keeping the experience fresh.
6. [b]Low System Requirements[/b]
   SCP:SL runs smoothly on most systems, making it an accessible option for players with older hardware.
---
[h1]Cons:[/h1]

1. [b]Technical Issues and Bugs[/b]
   Players often report optimization issues, occasional bugs, and performance drops—especially on crowded servers.
2. [b]Steep Learning Curve[/b]
   Understanding all the classes, mechanics, and strategies can be overwhelming for newcomers. The game does not offer much onboard guidance.
3. [b]Role Imbalance[/b]
   Some roles (especially certain SCPs) can feel too strong or too weak depending on the match, leading to balance complaints.
4. [b]Toxic Players / Server Problems[/b]
   As with many multiplayer games, some servers may have toxic players or unbalanced rules, affecting the experience.
5. [b]Random Role Assignment[/b]
   Roles at the beginning of matches are often completely random, which can frustrate players who want to consistently play as specific classes or SCPs.

---
[h1]Conclusion & Recommendation:[/h1]

[b]SCP: Secret Laboratory[/b] offers a chaotic, tense, and highly entertaining multiplayer experience—especially for fans of the SCP universe. If you enjoy teamwork, unpredictable encounters, and strategic survival gameplay, this game is absolutely worth trying. The fact that it’s free is a huge bonus.

However, be prepared for a learning curve, occasional bugs, and the typical issues that come with player-run servers.

[b]Overall:[/b] A fun, unique, and surprisingly deep multiplayer experience—definitely worth a shot.

SCP: Secret Laboratory has a cool concept, but in practice it’s a frustrating and unpolished experience. The gameplay feels chaotic in all the wrong ways—controls are clunky, hit detection is inconsistent, and the AI (both human and SCP) is unpredictable, often punishing you unfairly.

The maps are poorly designed in places, with confusing layouts and hiding spots that feel cheap rather than strategic. Matches often devolve into random chaos where luck matters far more than skill, making even successful runs feel hollow. The progression system is minimal, and the game offers little reward for repeated play, which makes it feel repetitive very quickly.

Performance issues are common. Lag, desync, and occasional crashes break the immersion, and the game feels rough around the edges despite being around for years. Communication is key in multiplayer, but the interface makes coordination awkward, leaving teamwork frustrating rather than fun.

SCP: Secret Laboratory has the bones of an interesting horror multiplayer, but clunky mechanics, unbalanced gameplay, and technical issues turn it into a grindy, stressful, and often unfair experience.

Final Rating: 3.7 / 10

I've played this game back when it was like 7 or 8 months old so I guess I can have some kind of an opinion on this game and what it has become over the years.
I really miss the times where it was more focused the horror aspects of SCPs rather than on escaping as fast as possible and being a genuine sweatass. I really don't get why there is this itchy need to rework everything and make it more "realistic" rather than just add new and fun stuff to an SCP game - a game based on pure fiction and fantasies.
Where are the horror stingers? Why is the facility so bright? Why do the rounds need to end up a battle royale match instead of focusing on killing SCPs and the quirky social interactions? Why are the SCPs reworked to be juked rather than left to be a living horror you should avoid at all costs, and if you fail - you die with a single click of a button, not dozens of them if you're "skilled" enough (stacked with 3 medkits and some 500s). Why am I supposed to outlive 049's touch? How is 096 unable to rip me apart the moment it gets my hands onto me? Why is 939 unable to talk to human classes now?I have to admit, stealing voices of the dead is honestly amazing, but talking to the living gave so many opportunities for either funny or semi-scary situations. Why does everything need to be balanced so much it's not really fun anymore? I remember when 330s could transform me into a funny candy monster or make me explode - and now it's gone because it was "unbalanced". Even the hands cutting thing doesn't work properly - they fall beneath you, but at the same time, your playermodel (and soon ragdoll of it) still has them attached.
This whole game blew up back then because it was both scary and silly at times. It wasn't because it was a "super realistic, real life based SCP game with even more realistic pew pew gun mechanics".
I really want to enjoy this game and love it like I loved it years ago, but I truly can't.
